results.title: The School of Stanley J. Ellis
results.brief_description:
A short history of Stanley J. Ellis (b. 1899), influential artisan and teacher in the field of decorative metalwork and enamelling whose intricate work represents some of the finest examples of craftsmanship to be produced in the arts and craft movement of early 20th century Australia. His work is permanently held at the Castlemaine Art Gallery and Museum in regional Victoria and in this film we see some of those highly acclaimed pieces. The film also features interviews with Peter Perry (Director, Castlemaine Art Gallery and Museum) and Beth Sinclair, one of Ellis’s students.
Filmed by Malcolm McKinnon and made in association with the Castlemaine Art Gallery and Museum.

results.title: Remembering a champion
results.brief_description:
Made in collaboration with Lockington and Districts Living Heritage Complex, this short, comprising of stills, archival excerpts and narrative commentary, celebrates the memory of Kevin Sarre - a champion in an era when a “gun shearer” was something like a pop star.
Made by Malcolm McKinnon and featuring Margaret O’Brien and Des Pentreath.
Excerpt from Australian Wool Board promotional film reproduced courtesy of the Arnold and Saare family collection and the Australian Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry.

results.title: A New dress (35 years of family sewing)
results.brief_description:
Bev Scott has been making clothes for her family for thirty years. To the sporadic background sound of a sewing machine, family members are interviewed showing their home-made clothes to describe the woman who created them.
Filmed by Malcolm McKinnon and featuring Bev Scott, Heather Scott, Robyn Ritchie, Erin Ritchie and Lauren Ritchie. Made in collaboration with Showcase Wangaratta.

results.title: Mourning & memory (a fabric memorial)
results.brief_description:
Short documentary about the Korean War Honour Roll Quilt made by the Coleraine Sit and Sew Group to commemorate the 340 Australian soldiers killed in the Korean War. Includes stills and personal commentary from the Coleraine community and some of those who contributed to the 1000 hours of work it took to complete the quilt.
Made by Malcolm McKinnon and featuring Nola Gunning, Sherri Robertson, Maurie Butterworth, Lynn Gunning, Melba Plush and Janet Stanton.

results.title: Dad's goanna
results.brief_description:
One of two stories in MAP about the stuffed animal displays in the Murtoa Museum. In this short doco, Meryl Duder talks about her life in Murtoa as a young girl of 10, relating the tale of “dad’s goanna” and how it ended up preserved in Mr Hill’s house in Murtoa in a room full of many other stuffed animals. Years later, on returning to Murtoa with her daughter and to the Murtoa Museum, Meryl was delighted to be able to point out and say “there’s dad’s goanna”.
Filmed by Malcolm McKinnon and made with the assistance of Murtoa Historical Society and Murtoa Lions Club.
The James Hill Bird Collection is held by the Lions Club of Murtoa under a special scientific license.

results.title: Brimbank beat
results.brief_description:
In 2004, Brimbank City Council secured funding from Arts Victoria to engage an artist to work with local residents, from diverse locales, ages and backgrounds, to produce a compelling historical and contemporary sweep of life across the municipality. Artist Angela Bailey began work on the project in mid 2004. Angela worked closely with a host of contributors to collect stories , photos and moving images that provide vignettes of the local characters, cultures, interests and passions that drive the Brimbank heart beat. The Brimbank Beat CD-Rom is the result of this endeavour but there are other less tangible outcomes. Friendships were formed along the way and here, in this compilation of disparate interests and backgrounds emerges a single municipality called Brimbank.
The historical film footage that is featured on Brimbank beat is from a film by the Victorian filmmaker John Henry Jackson.

results.title: Memory
results.brief_description:
“When an elephant lost his memory, a goldfish tried to help him to remember his past with her limited memory. The elephant couldn’t remember anything. He even forgot the goldfish. At last, the elephant just left everything behind and walked away.”
Slow-moving, visually provocative and backed by a haunting soundtrack,
this work has a surrealistic quality that engages the viewer. Its allegorical theme of memory is beautifully portrayed through a conversation between a man and a woman,and their relationship to one another. Filmed in black and white with English subtitles.

results.title: The Tree outside my house
results.brief_description:
The concept of the project was to represent the process of establishing data. The data was established as a set of 20 facts about the tree outside my house. The representations of the processes were to be strongly associated with my memories of learning and using these processes.
Initially the concept of the project only dealt with the
visualisation of the height of the tree and the process to
establish that fact. The visualisation of this process was to
be based on my childhood memories of a school activity.
The initial concept was later widened to include 20 facts
about the tree.
I was more interested in the processes used to establish
the facts than the facts themselves. I wanted to explore my memories and visually represent the process as a memory. The processes I wanted to represent were tied to the following facts:
•The name of the tree
•The botanical name of the tree
•The distance from the tree
•The angle to the top of the tree
•The height equals distance multiplied by pi
•The height of the tree
•The width of the trunk
•The volume of the tree
•The age of the tree
•The colour of the bark in RGB
•The colour of the bark in hexadecimal
•The bark’s range and difference of colours
•The shape of the leaves
•The colour of the leaves
•The size of the leaves
•The area of the leaves
•The noise of the wind in the leaves of the tree
•The number of branches
•The location of the tree

results.title: There's no place like earth
results.brief_description:
Fantastic interactive work created as part of Project Snap by digital artist Ruth Fleishman and writer Jacinta Parsons in collaboration with local programmer Mark Johnson and Grade 5/6 students of Footscray West Primary on the topic of their local environment.
Each class concentrated on a different environmental theme and combined that with their study of the earth’s atmosphere. The themes include: Earth’s crust; Waterways; Earth’s surface; Troposphere - pollution; Troposphere - global warming.
